You're forgetting that the gravity reaching that ring would not be spread equally around it as you say, due to the rest of the planet covering up the center that's generating the gravity, however unevenly.

My point is that, the place in the ring that would be, let's say, parallel to Australia, wouldn't be affected by the same gravitational pull as one that's parallel to most/some other point on Earth. So naturally, the one parallel to the strongest gravitational pull out of all of them (or a point that acts as a combination of all the influential gravitational pulls) would smash into Earth. Potentially smashing into Earth numerous times afterwards on different points, if the gravitational pull wasn't one sided enough to keep it there.

My guess would be that it would buckle or impact the surface at some point because of differences in the earth's gravitational field. One area with more gravity would cause the ring to fall or collapse there with more structural stress occurring in other parts of the ring (especially if you include natural flaws in manufacturing).

Technicaly if you blow up the supports holding up the ring then that means that the ring will have inertia and angular momentum about the earth's spinning axis. So yes, it will spin like crazy but to us it seems still because it is spinning at the same rate as us. On another note, the spinning will also cause centrifugal force on the ring(if it is places on the poles). If the ring is strong enough, (or it is positioned along the equator), it may hold up, but if it isn't, centrifugal force will pull the ends along the equator out and thus, making the system even more unstable than it was before. If it does collapse, it will likely create a spectacular meteor shower at the poles and around them, and possibly fly out into space at the equator ends. But then again, the moon's gravity hasn't even been accounted for yet in this system. With the moon included, the system will likely collapse in a very short amount of time...

I appreciate posting a footnote to correct the unstable equilibrium issue, however I still downvoted this video, for two reasons:

1. It seems there is no mention in the video itself about this. You should post a text box around the time you talk about the solid ring, which says it is unstable and links to the footnote. As it stands the video is too misleading.

2. It's not like the error is in some minor issue. The whole point of the video is to explain what would happen to such a ring. And your answer to what will happen is just wrong (you say it will stay in place, but it will not - it will crash in about 6 hours). That's remarkably negligent and pointless.

I suggest seriously considering removing this video and posting a new one that integrates the footnote. (And maybe this time try not to laugh awkwardly while talking about the explosives).

But even if you just fix #1 I will remove the downvote.

I think whether or not the ring moves is dependent on how it's positioned relative to the equatorial bulge of the earth right? If it's  perfectly around the equator it won't spin, or if it is perfectly polar  it shouldn't spin either, but if it's somewhere in between there is an imbalance of torques which should cause it to rotate. The rate of rotation would be dependent on the altitude of ring too. I'm thinking it's analogous to nodal regression of spacecraft orbits.

if the ring was installed directly attached to the earth, it would be spinning with the earth. blow up the supports, and it would continue to spin with the earth for a while, but eventually outside gravitational forces (like the tidal pull of the moon) would act on it. also, the earth is an ellipsoid, not a perfect sphere, making the gravitational pull from within uneven as its rotation falls out of sync with earth's. i'm not saying i have the answer for what would happen then, but there are definitely a few key variables that need to be factored in for a more accurate answer...

Suppose the ring was built along the rotational equator of the earth (i.e. in line with the plane normal to the axis of rotation), and was accelerated so that the ring had an angular velocity that would cause the translational velocity of any section of the ring to be at orbital velocity. At this point each section of the ring will experience gravitational attraction but also (due to the nature of orbits) accelerate outwards equally to result in no change in radial distance for any given part of the ring. Would this ring be stable?

The altitude of the ring matters. If the ring is within the atmosphere, it's either indestructible or will buckle or break, but there is a stable point at a high enough orbit where the ring will break up, but as long as the ring gained enough angular inertia before breaking, the fragments will stay in place. Beyond that, they will drift away from the Earth, like the moon does

You know how if you drive a car in a fast circle, the driver and passengers will feel the centrifugal force to the outside of the circle. Faster the circle, greater the force.

Replace car with spaceship and circle with orbit.

How fast would the spaceship need to circle or orbit the earth for the astronauts to feel the centrifugal force?

I'm assuming it exceeds the escape velocity of the earth's gravity well. So how much additional "downward" force would be needed to be added to stay in Earth's orbit?

And finally. Where would the direction of that centrifugal force be with the sum of the "forward" and "downward" forces to the perspective of the astronauts and spaceship?

Your answers presumes there is no moon and no sun and that the earth is perfectly round without any mountain nor any change in density all around its circumference.  It also presumes there is no wind to cause this sensitive equilibrium to get out of balance.  Put simply:  such a system can not maintain its equilibrium and would fall and if it would not break, it would start moving a lot like tides and the wind does move.  Its stability would depend on too many factors too hard to control...

would it be theoretically possible to balance a weak ring so perfectly so that it wouldn't buckle, since there where no imperfections for the buckle to start at?

Only one problem with this called the avalanche effect. It is impossible for a ring to be perfectly balanced among all positions simultaneously.....and even if so, you still have random effects such as wind or solar flare. This simple "nudge" (even as small as a piece of dust) in the wrong spot can give just the right amount of acceleration towards the ground. As that part gets closer, the gravity becomes stronger for it, and the opposing side gets further from the gravity well, increasing acceleration faster.

The ring will crash, regardless. You would need stabilizers to retain "orbit" (if you can call it that)

Your answer didn't address the question of the orbital velocity of the right. Is the ring spinning in a geosynchronous speed, where the same portion of the ring is always over the same part of the earth or not? Also, what's the altitude?

If the ring is geosynchronous, and in the Asimov zone, then destroying the supports wouldn't have an affect since the ring is essentially in the 0G zone, however, if the ring is at a lower altitude, then stresses from the lower rotational speed vs altitude would cause it to collapse.

It's "technically" possible with modern technology, and definitely possible with modern science. You use active support, a massive superconductive mass accelerator around the Earth. You can keep low temperatures for superconductors much easier cause space.This accelerator moves charged matter(rocks whatever) using magnetic field, the forces that move the matter also create a force on the ring that cancels gravity. Then you tie it to earth so that it doesn't wobble around, and you've got yourself an orbital ring.
It's the cheapest way to put things into orbit that we know of, and doubles up as a great transportation system for moving around earth. And we can just spin ships up and throw them for interplanetary travel. A ring like that isn't very practical right now, but it's a great way for an interplanetary or even K2 civilization to handle the insane amount of traffic they would generate. And you can use it for planet disassembly if you are into Dyson swarms.

If the ring was held up by poles in the first place, that means it was geostationary (same rotational velocity as earth), so if the poles were to break (and assuming the ring didn't fall\break) then it would continue spinning as it were, and still stay geostationary (aka it will not spin/move from the viewpoint of a person on earth).

If the ring was put right above the equator, and with a radius of ~42,15 [KM], then all of its parts would be in geostationary orbit, meaning that they would be in zero-g, in that case, even if the ring was structurally very weak, it would still stay up (like geostationary satellites that have the same rotational velocity as earth)

Everyone keeps mentioning uneven gravity as if that's the only issue with this whole thing. If the ring is spinning quickly, I believe it will precess (verb of precession?) instead of fall. As it spins faster, it will be easier to maintain its shape. The structure will experience the least stress at orbital velocity I think, and any faster will make it experience an outward force (opposite direction of gravity).
